Description: Steatite scarab roughly engraved with the praenomen of Thothmosis III (Men-kheper-Ra) in Egyptian hieroglyphic characters; linear patterns in the exergue and area above the characters, described as lotus flowers in the printed catalogue of gems, the latter possibly representing the name of Ptah.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Turner Bequest Excavations, Curium
Curator's comments: Kenna (1971, p. 35) considers the scarab a possible Cypriot production, based on the rendering of the Egyptian motifs which he suggests resemble a Cypriot glyptic manner. Jacobsson dates the seal to the 19th or 20th Dynasty. Dr Marcel Maree of the Department of Egypt and Sudan has confirmed that the form of the motifs are no later than the New Kingdom, in which case a Late Bronze Age date is likely. This suggests the item was an heirloom when depoisited in the tomb.
Bibliographic references: Gem / Catalogue of Engraved Gems & Cameos, Greek, Etruscan & Roman in the British Museum (152)
Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (p. 81, Tomb 1, no. 1; pl. IV, Curium 2)
Kenna 1971 / Catalogue of the Cypriote Seals of the Bronze Age in the British Museum (No. 119, p. 35)
Jacobsson 1994 / Aegyptiaca from Late Bronze Age Cyprus (No. 248)
